File: /src/juice-shop/lib/insecurity.ts
Code: algorithm: 'RS256' })
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-31
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: eb0c7dcf061caeaeefdb37dc6e0906b4c4fefca4cbb05b4d2c0da455ef0eee0f
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: JWT should be signed and verified with strong cipher algorithms
If a JSON Web Token (JWT) is not signed with a strong cipher algorithm (or not signed at all) an attacker can forge it and impersonate user identities. Don't use none algorithm to sign or verify the validity of an algorithm. Don't use a token without verifying its signature before. For more information checkout the CWE-347 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/347.html) advisory.

For more information checkout the CWE-798 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/798.html) advisory.

For more information checkout the CWE-798 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/798.html) advisory.

For more information checkout the CWE-798 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/798.html) advisory.

Language: Leaks
Severity: CRITICAL
Line: 0
Column: 0
SecurityTool: HorusecEngine
Confidence: MEDIUM
File: /src/juice-shop/frontend/dist/frontend/202.js
Code: 
RuleID: HS-LEAKS-2
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 41d86dbfeace4c6b2b6ab2a45b21e1c6187c04622fd007d126d6331e2cb10f42
Details: (1/4) * Possible vulnerability detected: AWS Secret Key
When use AWS Secret Key is recommended use vault or environment variable encrypted for the best security. For more information checkout the CWE-798 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/798.html) advisory.
         
(2/4) * Possible vulnerability detected: Origins should be verified during cross-origin communications
Browsers allow message exchanges between Window objects of different origins. Because any window can send / receive messages from other window it is important to verify the sender's / receiver's identity: When sending message with postMessage method, the identity's receiver should be defined (the wildcard keyword (*) should not be used).
When receiving message with message event, the sender's identity should be verified using the origin and possibly source properties. For more information checkout the OWASP A2:2017 (https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/2017/A2_2017-Broken_Authentication) and (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/postMessage) advisory.
         
(3/4) * Possible vulnerability detected: Debugger statements should not be used
The debugger statement can be placed anywhere in procedures to suspend execution. Using the debugger statement is similar to setting a breakpoint in the code. By definition such statement must absolutely be removed from the source code to prevent any unexpected behavior or added vulnerability to attacks in production. For more information checkout the CWE-489 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/489.html) advisory.
         
(4/4) * Possible vulnerability detected: No Log Sensitive Information in console
The App logs information. Sensitive information should never be logged. For more information checkout the CWE-532 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/532.html) advisory.

Language: Leaks
Severity: CRITICAL
Line: 0
Column: 0
SecurityTool: HorusecEngine
Confidence: MEDIUM
File: /src/juice-shop/frontend/dist/frontend/98.js
Code: 
RuleID: HS-LEAKS-2
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: b34618e23a4e02878e98ee42bec0d985e6087b2cf1b64b14e85053048d0a1463
Details: (1/5) * Possible vulnerability detected: AWS Secret Key
When use AWS Secret Key is recommended use vault or environment variable encrypted for the best security. For more information checkout the CWE-798 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/798.html) advisory.
         
(2/5) * Possible vulnerability detected: Potential Hard-coded credential
The software contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data. For more information checkout the CWE-798 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/798.html) advisory.
         
(3/5) * Possible vulnerability detected: No use weak random number generator
When software generates predictable values in a context requiring unpredictability, it may be possible for an attacker to guess the next value that will be generated, and use this guess to impersonate another user or access sensitive information. As the Math.random() function relies on a weak pseudorandom number generator, this function should not be used for security-critical applications or for protecting sensitive data. In such context, a cryptographically strong pseudorandom number generator (CSPRNG) should be used instead. For more information checkout the CWE-338 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/338.html) advisory.
         
(4/5) * Possible vulnerability detected: Insecure download of executable file
Downloading executables or other sensitive files over an unencrypted connection can leave a server open to man-in-the-middle attacks (MITM). Such an attack can allow an attacker to insert arbitrary content into the downloaded file, and in the worst case, allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code on the vulnerable system.. For more information checkout the CWE-829 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/829.html) advisory.
         
(5/5) * Possible vulnerability detected: No Log Sensitive Information in console
The App logs information. Sensitive information should never be logged. For more information checkout the CWE-532 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/532.html) advisory.

==================================================================================

Language: Leaks
Severity: CRITICAL
Line: 0
Column: 0
SecurityTool: HorusecEngine
Confidence: MEDIUM
File: /src/juice-shop/frontend/dist/frontend/main.js
Code: 
RuleID: HS-LEAKS-26
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: f93744d47e43b3bd7609f3bedba07cadce0268d66ef63312ec54100c80fe875b
Details: (1/8) * Possible vulnerability detected: Hard-coded password
The software contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data. For more information checkout the CWE-798 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/798.html) advisory.
         
(2/8) * Possible vulnerability detected: Origins should be verified during cross-origin communications
Browsers allow message exchanges between Window objects of different origins. Because any window can send / receive messages from other window it is important to verify the sender's / receiver's identity: When sending message with postMessage method, the identity's receiver should be defined (the wildcard keyword (*) should not be used).
When receiving message with message event, the sender's identity should be verified using the origin and possibly source properties. For more information checkout the OWASP A2:2017 (https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/2017/A2_2017-Broken_Authentication) and (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/postMessage) advisory.
         
(3/8) * Possible vulnerability detected: Debugger statements should not be used
The debugger statement can be placed anywhere in procedures to suspend execution. Using the debugger statement is similar to setting a breakpoint in the code. By definition such statement must absolutely be removed from the source code to prevent any unexpected behavior or added vulnerability to attacks in production. For more information checkout the CWE-489 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/489.html) advisory.
         
(4/8) * Possible vulnerability detected: Alert statements should not be used
alert(...) as well as confirm(...) and prompt(...) can be useful for debugging during development, but in production mode this kind of pop-up could expose sensitive information to attackers, and should never be displayed. For more information checkout the CWE-489 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/489.html) advisory.
         
(5/8) * Possible vulnerability detected: No use weak random number generator
When software generates predictable values in a context requiring unpredictability, it may be possible for an attacker to guess the next value that will be generated, and use this guess to impersonate another user or access sensitive information. As the Math.random() function relies on a weak pseudorandom number generator, this function should not be used for security-critical applications or for protecting sensitive data. In such context, a cryptographically strong pseudorandom number generator (CSPRNG) should be used instead. For more information checkout the CWE-338 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/338.html) advisory.
         
(6/8) * Possible vulnerability detected: Insecure download of executable file
Downloading executables or other sensitive files over an unencrypted connection can leave a server open to man-in-the-middle attacks (MITM). Such an attack can allow an attacker to insert arbitrary content into the downloaded file, and in the worst case, allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code on the vulnerable system.. For more information checkout the CWE-829 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/829.html) advisory.
         
(7/8) * Possible vulnerability detected: Local storage should not be used
Session storage and local storage are HTML 5 features which allow developers to easily store megabytes of data client-side, as opposed to the 4Kb cookies can accommodate. While useful to speed applications up on the client side, it can be dangerous to store sensitive information this way because the data is not encrypted by default and any script on the page may access it. This rule raises an issue when the localStorage and sessionStorage API's are used. For more information checkout the OWSAP A3:2017 (https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/2017/A3_2017-Sensitive_Data_Exposure.html) advisory.
         
(8/8) * Possible vulnerability detected: No Log Sensitive Information in console
The App logs information. Sensitive information should never be logged. For more information checkout the CWE-532 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/532.html) advisory.

File: /src/juice-shop/build/routes/delivery.js
Code: const method = await delivery_1.DeliveryModel.findOne({ where: { id: req.params.id } });
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-9
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 67c32d696667c67864e2717ca796ffabf0d6e1446559828367dc9c6aadc1b0aa
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: SQL Injection Using params
Passing untreated parameters to queries in the database can cause an injection of SQL / NoSQL. The attacker is able to insert a custom and improper SQL statement through the data entry of an application. Language: JavaScript
Severity: HIGH
Line: 146
Column: 48
SecurityTool: HorusecEngine
Confidence: MEDIUM
File: /src/juice-shop/frontend/src/app/code-snippet/code-snippet.component.ts
Code: .map((fix, index) => ({ fix, index, sort: Math.random() }))
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-6
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 72f94ee55f475511a86e59b62714cc5d76bce22083a9def56f8a3d76c34e9b7f
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: No use weak random number generator
When software generates predictable values in a context requiring unpredictability, it may be possible for an attacker to guess the next value that will be generated, and use this guess to impersonate another user or access sensitive information. As the Math.random() function relies on a weak pseudorandom number generator, this function should not be used for security-critical applications or for protecting sensitive data. In such context, a cryptographically strong pseudorandom number generator (CSPRNG) should be used instead. For more information checkout the CWE-338 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/338.html) advisory.

Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: Alert statements should not be used
alert(...) as well as confirm(...) and prompt(...) can be useful for debugging during development, but in production mode this kind of pop-up could expose sensitive information to attackers, and should never be displayed. Arbitrary OS command injection vulnerabilities are more likely when a shell is spawned rather than a new process, indeed shell meta-chars can be used (when parameters are user-controlled for instance) to inject OS commands. Language: JavaScript
Severity: HIGH
Line: 58
Column: 25
SecurityTool: HorusecEngine
Confidence: MEDIUM
File: /src/juice-shop/build/routes/login.js
Code: ELECT * FROM Users WHERE email = '${req.body.email || ''}' AND password = '${security.hash(req.body.
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-53
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 009c02fc5666bfebd490647cf5f0c273fe6f128009d842f7b667142e00003079
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: SQL Injection
SQL queries often need to use a hardcoded SQL string with a dynamic parameter coming from a user request. Formatting a string to add those parameters to the request is a bad practice as it can result in an SQL injection. The safe way to add parameters to a SQL query is to use SQL binding mechanisms. For more information checkout the CWE-564 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/564.html) and OWASP A1:2017 (https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/2017/A1_2017-Injection.html) advisory.

Often, this is done by checking that the host of a URL is in a set of allowed hosts. For more information checkout the CWE-20 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/20.html) advisory.

RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-53
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 5eb9914b57678e53d3a44a016fa03188707f0e182de51876e16c6b8d89b3078a
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: SQL Injection
SQL queries often need to use a hardcoded SQL string with a dynamic parameter coming from a user request. Formatting a string to add those parameters to the request is a bad practice as it can result in an SQL injection. The safe way to add parameters to a SQL query is to use SQL binding mechanisms. For more information checkout the CWE-564 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/564.html) and OWASP A1:2017 (https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/2017/A1_2017-Injection.html) advisory.

Language: JavaScript
Severity: HIGH
Line: 0
Column: 0
SecurityTool: HorusecEngine
Confidence: MEDIUM
File: /src/juice-shop/frontend/dist/frontend/859.js
Code: 
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-11
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: e310b4d157202fe218afe2d0149b91e24e881294cbb9c9e3c82481f3bd12de78
Details: (1/2) * Possible vulnerability detected: Origins should be verified during cross-origin communications
Browsers allow message exchanges between Window objects of different origins. Because any window can send / receive messages from other window it is important to verify the sender's / receiver's identity: When sending message with postMessage method, the identity's receiver should be defined (the wildcard keyword (*) should not be used).
When receiving message with message event, the sender's identity should be verified using the origin and possibly source properties. For more information checkout the OWASP A2:2017 (https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/2017/A2_2017-Broken_Authentication) and (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/postMessage) advisory.
         
(2/2) * Possible vulnerability detected: No Log Sensitive Information in console
The App logs information. Sensitive information should never be logged. For more information checkout the CWE-532 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/532.html) advisory.

Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: Debugger statements should not be used
The debugger statement can be placed anywhere in procedures to suspend execution. Using the debugger statement is similar to setting a breakpoint in the code. By definition such statement must absolutely be removed from the source code to prevent any unexpected behavior or added vulnerability to attacks in production. For more information checkout the CWE-489 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/489.html) advisory.

For more information checkout the CWE-89 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/89.html) advisory.

Language: JavaScript
Severity: HIGH
Line: 15
Column: 34
SecurityTool: HorusecEngine
Confidence: MEDIUM
File: /src/juice-shop/routes/captcha.ts
Code: const firstTerm = Math.floor((Math.random() * 10) + 1)
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-6
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 230f4988493f81c5754aa37965933a27dc6e1887b486c1c238cf345ed1e85f4e
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: No use weak random number generator
When software generates predictable values in a context requiring unpredictability, it may be possible for an attacker to guess the next value that will be generated, and use this guess to impersonate another user or access sensitive information. As the Math.random() function relies on a weak pseudorandom number generator, this function should not be used for security-critical applications or for protecting sensitive data. In such context, a cryptographically strong pseudorandom number generator (CSPRNG) should be used instead. For more information checkout the CWE-338 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/338.html) advisory.

Code: const md5 = crypto.createHash('md5')
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-4
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: f9e73713d2a7bd244b2ce76da550606ea944346fdc224238e6c14e65ee69c046
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: No use MD5 hashing
The MD5 hash algorithm that was used is considered weak. It can also cause hash collisions. It is always recommended to use some CHF (Cryptographic Hash Function), which is mathematically strong and not reversible. SHA512 would be the most recommended hash for storing the password and it is also important to adopt some type of Salt, so that the Hash is more secure. For more information checkout the CWE-327 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/327.html) advisory.

Language: JavaScript

File: /src/juice-shop/data/static/codefixes/loginAdminChallenge_2.ts
Code: y(`SELECT * FROM Users WHERE email = $1 AND password = '${security.hash(req.body.password || '')}' A
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-53
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 1db71de1fab212e3bdfa7b5db33b54b76a3ef42fc86a4825bbe6114e48008b5d
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: SQL Injection
SQL queries often need to use a hardcoded SQL string with a dynamic parameter coming from a user request. Formatting a string to add those parameters to the request is a bad practice as it can result in an SQL injection. The safe way to add parameters to a SQL query is to use SQL binding mechanisms. For more information checkout the CWE-564 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/564.html) and OWASP A1:2017 (https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/2017/A1_2017-Injection.html) advisory.

Language: JavaScript
Severity: HIGH
Line: 43
Column: 45
SecurityTool: HorusecEngine
Confidence: MEDIUM
File: /src/juice-shop/lib/insecurity.ts
Code: export const hash = (data: string) => crypto.createHash('md5').update(data).digest('hex')
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-4
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: a1ebed59876ed68ebcae4e9ce7851d1d2a5771ac464d4b43bd7c06463faaf5eb
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: No use MD5 hashing
The MD5 hash algorithm that was used is considered weak. It can also cause hash collisions. It is always recommended to use some CHF (Cryptographic Hash Function), which is mathematically strong and not reversible. SHA512 would be the most recommended hash for storing the password and it is also important to adopt some type of Salt, so that the Hash is more secure. For more information checkout the CWE-327 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/327.html) advisory.

==================================================================================

Language: JavaScript
Severity: HIGH
Line: 55
Column: 55
SecurityTool: HorusecEngine
Confidence: MEDIUM
File: /src/juice-shop/lib/insecurity.ts
Code: export const denyAll = () => expressJwt({ secret: '' + Math.random() } as any)
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-6
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 8eb0ea593fb231b3c37dec9801c9bfe78b9415e8d3c85cc317c7e20822c1fbc4
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: No use weak random number generator
When software generates predictable values in a context requiring unpredictability, it may be possible for an attacker to guess the next value that will be generated, and use this guess to impersonate another user or access sensitive information. As the Math.random() function relies on a weak pseudorandom number generator, this function should not be used for security-critical applications or for protecting sensitive data. In such context, a cryptographically strong pseudorandom number generator (CSPRNG) should be used instead. For more information checkout the CWE-338 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/338.html) advisory.

==================================================================================

Language: JavaScript
Severity: HIGH
Line: 0
Column: 0
SecurityTool: HorusecEngine
Confidence: MEDIUM
File: /src/juice-shop/frontend/dist/frontend/103.js
Code: 
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-11
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 708d8a80976efdccb3cae97be617149e38940c0b244337c392fa02c232cafc6e
Details: (1/3) * Possible vulnerability detected: Origins should be verified during cross-origin communications
Browsers allow message exchanges between Window objects of different origins. Because any window can send / receive messages from other window it is important to verify the sender's / receiver's identity: When sending message with postMessage method, the identity's receiver should be defined (the wildcard keyword (*) should not be used).
When receiving message with message event, the sender's identity should be verified using the origin and possibly source properties. For more information checkout the OWASP A2:2017 (https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/2017/A2_2017-Broken_Authentication) and (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/postMessage) advisory.
         
(2/3) * Possible vulnerability detected: No use weak random number generator
When software generates predictable values in a context requiring unpredictability, it may be possible for an attacker to guess the next value that will be generated, and use this guess to impersonate another user or access sensitive information. As the Math.random() function relies on a weak pseudorandom number generator, this function should not be used for security-critical applications or for protecting sensitive data. In such context, a cryptographically strong pseudorandom number generator (CSPRNG) should be used instead. For more information checkout the CWE-338 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/338.html) advisory.
         
(3/3) * Possible vulnerability detected: No Log Sensitive Information in console
The App logs information. Sensitive information should never be logged. For more information checkout the CWE-532 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/532.html) advisory.

==================================================================================

When software generates predictable values in a context requiring unpredictability, it may be possible for an attacker to guess the next value that will be generated, and use this guess to impersonate another user or access sensitive information. As the Math.random() function relies on a weak pseudorandom number generator, this function should not be used for security-critical applications or for protecting sensitive data. In such context, a cryptographically strong pseudorandom number generator (CSPRNG) should be used instead. For more information checkout the CWE-338 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/338.html) advisory.

RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-15
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 3d88e2740145c186fb9af7b951bf9ec3c8c79718044785688a9fb1e3d1d6bd84
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: Debugger statements should not be used
The debugger statement can be placed anywhere in procedures to suspend execution. Using the debugger statement is similar to setting a breakpoint in the code. By definition such statement must absolutely be removed from the source code to prevent any unexpected behavior or added vulnerability to attacks in production. For more information checkout the CWE-489 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/489.html) advisory.

Language: JavaScript

File: /src/juice-shop/data/static/codefixes/loginBenderChallenge_1.ts
Code: y(`SELECT * FROM Users WHERE email = '${req.body.email || ''}' AND password = '${security.hash(req.b
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-53
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 92a4dcaf56b2f182519fe6a0eb45edd5feb212b39d997c543b13e4d0cd5e6650
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: SQL Injection
SQL queries often need to use a hardcoded SQL string with a dynamic parameter coming from a user request. Formatting a string to add those parameters to the request is a bad practice as it can result in an SQL injection. The safe way to add parameters to a SQL query is to use SQL binding mechanisms. For more information checkout the CWE-564 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/564.html) and OWASP A1:2017 (https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/2017/A1_2017-Injection.html) advisory.

Code: y(`SELECT * FROM Users WHERE email = '${req.body.email || ''}' AND password = '${security.hash(req.b
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-53
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 3dd070609c08b82f5d49df380f44041a6a5bc21bcae24167fe3d41d328f0a283
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: SQL Injection
SQL queries often need to use a hardcoded SQL string with a dynamic parameter coming from a user request. Formatting a string to add those parameters to the request is a bad practice as it can result in an SQL injection. The safe way to add parameters to a SQL query is to use SQL binding mechanisms. For more information checkout the CWE-564 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/564.html) and OWASP A1:2017 (https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/2017/A1_2017-Injection.html) advisory.

Language: JavaScript

SecurityTool: HorusecEngine
Confidence: MEDIUM
File: /src/juice-shop/build/lib/insecurity.js
Code: const hash = (data) => crypto_1.default.createHash('md5').update(data).digest('hex');
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-4
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 12244583475d8c24900f5055098d7e1425b2952bd5538227adff1e36e1142bcb
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: No use MD5 hashing
The MD5 hash algorithm that was used is considered weak. It can also cause hash collisions. It is always recommended to use some CHF (Cryptographic Hash Function), which is mathematically strong and not reversible. SHA512 would be the most recommended hash for storing the password and it is also important to adopt some type of Salt, so that the Hash is more secure. For more information checkout the CWE-327 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/327.html) advisory.

==================================================================================

Language: JavaScript
Severity: HIGH
Line: 62
Column: 64
SecurityTool: HorusecEngine
Confidence: MEDIUM
File: /src/juice-shop/build/lib/insecurity.js
Code: const denyAll = () => (0, express_jwt_1.default)({ secret: '' + Math.random() });
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-6
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 0881d6c2135d28c14a7e073066fbd7c64ca57223b800b3057ed628295c41495a
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: No use weak random number generator
When software generates predictable values in a context requiring unpredictability, it may be possible for an attacker to guess the next value that will be generated, and use this guess to impersonate another user or access sensitive information. As the Math.random() function relies on a weak pseudorandom number generator, this function should not be used for security-critical applications or for protecting sensitive data. In such context, a cryptographically strong pseudorandom number generator (CSPRNG) should be used instead. For more information checkout the CWE-338 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/338.html) advisory.

Language: JavaScript

Line: 115
Column: 13
SecurityTool: HorusecEngine
Confidence: MEDIUM
File: /src/juice-shop/frontend/src/hacking-instructor/helpers/helpers.ts
Code: element.addEventListener('click', () => { resolve() })
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-11
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 1371a895900a6f6d1a1381117437a99c0a45e529594dae0d7ae63485a308b424
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: Origins should be verified during cross-origin communications
Browsers allow message exchanges between Window objects of different origins. Because any window can send / receive messages from other window it is important to verify the sender's / receiver's identity: When sending message with postMessage method, the identity's receiver should be defined (the wildcard keyword (*) should not be used).
When receiving message with message event, the sender's identity should be verified using the origin and possibly source properties. For more information checkout the OWASP A2:2017 (https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/2017/A2_2017-Broken_Authentication) and (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/postMessage) advisory.

(2/2) * Possible vulnerability detected: Debugger statements should not be used
The debugger statement can be placed anywhere in procedures to suspend execution. Using the debugger statement is similar to setting a breakpoint in the code. By definition such statement must absolutely be removed from the source code to prevent any unexpected behavior or added vulnerability to attacks in production. For more information checkout the CWE-489 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/489.html) advisory.

SecurityTool: HorusecEngine
Confidence: HIGH
File: /src/juice-shop/frontend/dist/frontend/202.js
Code: 
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-15
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 41d86dbfeace4c6b2b6ab2a45b21e1c6187c04622fd007d126d6331e2cb10f42
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: Debugger statements should not be used
The debugger statement can be placed anywhere in procedures to suspend execution. Using the debugger statement is similar to setting a breakpoint in the code. By definition such statement must absolutely be removed from the source code to prevent any unexpected behavior or added vulnerability to attacks in production. For more information checkout the CWE-489 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/489.html) advisory.

==================================================================================

Language: JavaScript
Severity: HIGH
Line: 11789
Column: 10
SecurityTool: HorusecEngine
Confidence: MEDIUM
File: /src/juice-shop/frontend/src/assets/private/three.js
Code: request.addEventListener( 'load', function ( event ) {
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-11
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 3d02bcd6dfcd323efd4fe81b21d32e474d26046a7055bafb191b8088b37a23bf
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: Origins should be verified during cross-origin communications
Browsers allow message exchanges between Window objects of different origins. Because any window can send / receive messages from other window it is important to verify the sender's / receiver's identity: When sending message with postMessage method, the identity's receiver should be defined (the wildcard keyword (*) should not be used).
When receiving message with message event, the sender's identity should be verified using the origin and possibly source properties. For more information checkout the OWASP A2:2017 (https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/2017/A2_2017-Broken_Authentication) and (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/postMessage) advisory.

==================================================================================

Language: JavaScript
Severity: HIGH
Line: 6359
Column: 41
SecurityTool: HorusecEngine
Confidence: MEDIUM
File: /src/juice-shop/frontend/src/assets/private/three.js
Code: if (rnd <= 0x02) rnd = 0x2000000 + (Math.random()*0x1000000)|0;
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-6
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: f5f12646313ddcab1520574a8f11f7a159fff7de10d7fafddfcce2438f5223fa
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: No use weak random number generator
When software generates predictable values in a context requiring unpredictability, it may be possible for an attacker to guess the next value that will be generated, and use this guess to impersonate another user or access sensitive information. As the Math.random() function relies on a weak pseudorandom number generator, this function should not be used for security-critical applications or for protecting sensitive data. In such context, a cryptographically strong pseudorandom number generator (CSPRNG) should be used instead. For more information checkout the CWE-338 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/338.html) advisory.

==================================================================================

ReferenceHash: 27175e82532c67f488ebe8b7e657bbeb9b7c39897979b409b54635fb601a7239
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: Insecure download of executable file
Downloading executables or other sensitive files over an unencrypted connection can leave a server open to man-in-the-middle attacks (MITM). Such an attack can allow an attacker to insert arbitrary content into the downloaded file, and in the worst case, allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code on the vulnerable system.. For more information checkout the CWE-829 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/829.html) advisory.

Confidence: MEDIUM
File: /src/juice-shop/build/routes/profileImageUrlUpload.js
Code: const loggedInUser = security.authenticatedUsers.get(req.cookies.token);
RuleID: HS-JAVASCRIPT-28
Type: Vulnerability
ReferenceHash: 152681145588dd93ef10dcd0b91af591062993cbd3fbed9938cdec2acac4638a
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: No use .get method using data from request of user input
Allows user input data to be used as parameters for the 'request.get' method. Without proper handling, it could cause a Server Side Request Forgery vulnerability. Which is a type of exploitation in which an attacker abuses the functionality of a server, causing it to access or manipulate information in that server's domain. For more information checkout the CWE-918 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html) advisory.

ReferenceHash: 521d90076ccbd216a905dc25c764edb45ea8a195e8752bb39b51dd2714b00df9
Details: (1/1) * Possible vulnerability detected: Insecure download of executable file
Downloading executables or other sensitive files over an unencrypted connection can leave a server open to man-in-the-middle attacks (MITM). Such an attack can allow an attacker to insert arbitrary content into the downloaded file, and in the worst case, allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code on the vulnerable system.. For more information checkout the CWE-829 (https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/829.html) advisory.
